Education - Delhi School Education Act, 1973 (18 of 1973) - c S. 17(3) - Statement of fees to be filed with Director of Education (per majority) - Particulars that must be included Delhi Abibhavak Mahasangh, a federation of parents' association moved the Delhi High Court by a writ petition challenging the fee hike in various schools in Delhi. It was a public interest writ petition impleading thirty unaided recognised public schools. The grievance of the Mahasangh was that recognised private d unaided schools in Delhi were indulging in large-scale commercialisation of education which was against the public interest. That commercialisation had reached an alarming situation on account of failure of the Government to perform its statutory functions under the Delhi School Education Act, 1973 ("the Act"). One of the serious charges in the writ petition against the said unaided recognised schools was transfer of funds by the said schools to the society/trust and/or to other schools run by the same society/trust. In this connection, it was e alleged that there was an excess of income over expenditure under the head "Tuition fee" and further interest-free loans of huge amount had been taken from parents for giving admissions to children. It was also alleged that huge amounts collected under the head "Building fund" remained unspent. The key issue before the High Court was whether unaided recognised schools were indulging in commercialisation of education. The High Court found f from the reports submitted by inspection teams appointed by the Government that there were irregularities in the management of the accounts. Therefore, by the impugned judgment, directions were given regarding utilisation of tuition fees for payment of salaries of teachers and employees and also for utilisation of the surplus under the specific head of tuition fees. By the impugned judgment, the High Court declared that the said Act and the Rules framed thereunder prohibited transfer of funds from the schools to the society/trust or to other g schools run by the same society/trust and appointed a committee, the Duggal Committee, to examine the economics of each of the recognised unaided schools in Delhi. Being aggrieved, the unaided recognised schools and the Action Committee of Unaided Private Schools appealed to the Supreme Court. The following three points arose for determination: (1) Whether the Director of Education has the authority to regulate the quantum of fees charged by unaided schools under Section 17(3) of the Act? (2) Whether the direction issued on 15-12-1999 by the Director of Education under Section 24(3) of the Act stating inter alia that no fees/funds collected from parents/students shall be transferred from the Recognised Unaided School Fund to the society or trust or any other institution, is in conflict with Rule 177 of the Delhi School Education Rules, 1973 ("the Rules")? (3) Whether managements of recognised unaided schools are entitled to set up a Development Fund Account under the provisions of the Act? Partly allowing the appeals, the Supreme Court Held: Question (1): Regulation of quantum of fees Per majority In the matter of determination of the fee structure unaided educational institutions exercise a great autonomy as they, like any other citizen carrying on an occupation, are entitled to a reasonable surplus for development of education and expansion of the institution. Such institutions, it has been held, have to plan their investment and expenditure so as to generate profit. What is, however, prohibited is commercialisation of education. Hence a balance has to be struck between autonomy of such institutions and measures to be taken to prevent commercialisation of education. However, in none of the earlier cases has the Supreme Court defined the concept of reasonable surplus, profit, income and yield, which are the terms used in the various provisions of the Act. Therefore what constitutes reasonable surplus in the context of the provisions of the Act is the issue to be determined. (Paras 14 and 15) It is trite that economic forces have a role to play in the matter of fee fixation. The institutions should be permitted to make reasonable profits after providing for investment and expenditure. However, capitation fee and profiteering were held to be forbidden. Subject to the above two prohibitory parameters fees to be charged by the unaided educational institutions cannot be regulated. There could be no rigid fee structure. Each institute must have freedom to fix its own fee structure, after taking into account the need to generate funds to run the institution and to provide facilities necessary for the benefit of the students. They must be able to generate surplus which must be used for betterment and growth of that educational institution. The fee structure must be fixed keeping in mind the infrastructure and facilities available, investment made, salaries paid to teachers and staff, future plans for expansion and/or betterment of institution subject to two restrictions, namely, non- profiteering and non-charging of capitation fees. Surplus/profit can be generated but they shall be used for the benefit of that educational institution and cannot be diverted for any other use or purposes and cannot be used for personal gain or for other business or enterprise. State of A.P., (1993) 1 sec 645, held already overruled a The object of the Act is to provide better organisation and development of school education in Delhi and for matters connected thereto. Reading Sections 18(3) and (4) with Rules 172, 173, 174, 175 and 177 on one hand and Section 17(3) on the other hand, it is clear that under the Act, the Director of Education is authorised to regulate the fees and other charges to prevent commercialisation of education. (Para 17) b Every school is required to file a statement of fees every year before the ensuing academic session under Section 17(3) of the said Act with the Director of Education. Such statement will indicate estimated income of the school derived from fees, estimated current operational expenses towards salaries and allowances payable to employees in terms of Rule 177(1). Such estimate will also indicate provision for donation, gratuity, reserve fund and other items under c Rule 177 (2) and savings thereafter, if any, in terms of the proviso to Rule 177 ( 1 ). (Para 27) The interpretation that has been placed on the provisions of the said Act is only to bring in transparency, accountability, expenditure management and utilisation of savings for capital expenditure/investment without infringement of the autonomy of the institute in the matter of fee fixation. It is also to prevent d commercialisation of education to the extent possible. (Para 26) Per Sinha, J. ( dissenting) The said Act and the Rules framed thereunder provide for a complete code not only as regards regulation of education but also organisation and development thereof. By reason of the provisions of the Act, school education, whether imparted in a government institution, a minority institution, an aided or unaided private institution is sought to be regulated. A necessary corollary e whereof would be that education imparted in an individual institution may also be subjected to regulation. The Act does not provide for any regulation as regards charging of any fee or any other amount by unaided recognised schools. (Paras 31 and 33) An eleven-Judge Bench as also a Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court in T.M.A. Pai, (2002) 8 SCC 481 and Islamic Academy, (2003) 6 SCC 697, have f merely forbidden profiteering. It would not be proper to impose any further restrictions in this behalf and interpret T.M.A. Pai in a different way so as to take away some of the rights of the appellants which are recognised therein. T.M.A. Pai gave a new look to the concept of "education" viz. opening up of economy and concept of globalisation. The question cannot therefore be looked at differently. (Paras 60 to 64) g T.M.A. Pai Foundation v. State of Kamataka, (2002) 8 SCC 481; Islamic Academy of Education v. State of Kamataka, (2003) 6 SCC 697, relied on Black's Law Dictionary, 5th Edn.; Singh, G.P.: Principles of Statutory Interpretation, 9th Edn., 2004, pp. 120-22, referred to The principles for fixing fee structure of particular institutions have been illustrated in T.M.A. Pai and Islamic Academy; but it must be borne in mind that those principles were laid down in absence of any statute operating in the field. h Where, however, a statute operates in the field, regulation of education would be ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. In this case, as the regulation of education is governed by a legislative Act, the court cannot impose any other or further restrictions by travelling beyond the scope, object and purport thereof. (Paras 40, 46 and 50) T.M.A. Pai Foundation v. State of Kamataka, (2002) 8 SCC 481; Islamic Academy of Education v. State of Kamataka, (2003) 6 SCC 697; Union of India v. Naveen Jindal, (2004) 2 sec 510, relied on Once the legislature has laid down an educational scheme, the jurisdiction of the court is merely to interpret the same. It cannot and should not issue any other or further direction. It would not supplant a statutory provision by issuing any direction except in some exceptional cases. It must further be borne in mind that by reason of judicial direction the Supreme Court cannot override a statute or statutory rules governing the field and, thus, no direction can be issued by the Supreme Court contrary thereto or inconsistent therewith. The Supreme Court normally does not pass an order even in exercise of its jurisdiction under Article 142 of the Constitution which would be contrary to the law. The need of the day, therefore, is strict implementation and enforcement of the statute. (Paras 64, 66 to 68) Govt. of W.B. v. Tarun K. Roy, (2004) 1 SCC 347 : 2004 SCC (L&S) 225 : (2003) 9 Scale 671; Jamshed Hormusji Wadia v. Board of Trustees, Port of Mumbai, (2004) 3 SCC 214, relied on Indisputably, the standard of education, the curricular and co-curricular activities available to the students and various other factors are matters which are relevant for determining the fee structure. Furthermore, while undertaking such exercise the respective cases of each institution, their plans and programmes for future expansion and several other factors are required to be taken into consideration. The courts of law having no expertise in the matter and/or having regard to their own limitations keeping in view the principles of judicial review always refrain from laying down precise formulae in such matters. (Paras 51 to 53) Bromley London Borough Council v. Greater London Council, (1983) 1 AC 768 : (1982) 1 All ER 129 : (1982) 2 WLR 62 (HL); International Transport Roth GmbH v. Secy. of State for the Home Deptt., 2002 EWCA Civ 158 : (2002) 3 WLR 344; Adams v. Lord Advocate, Court of Session, Times, 8-8-2002; Chairman and M.D., BPL Ltd. v. S.P. Gururaja, (2003) 8 SCC 567, cited Dawn Oliver: Constitutional Reform in the UK - ''The Courts and Theories of Democracy, Citizenship, and Good Governance" at p. 105, referred to The High Court by reason of the impugned judgment travelled beyond the legislative scheme as regards administration of a private institution as also fixation of fee while issuing the impugned directions in the light of the decision of the Supreme Court in Unni Krishnan, (1993) 1 SCC 645. Unni Krishnan no longer holds the field. Its dictum that imparting of education is not a fundamental right stands overruled. The scheme framed by it has also been held to be unconstitutional. All orders and directions issued by the High Court pursuant to or in furtherance of the directions in Unni Krishnan or any decision following the same must, therefore, be kept out of consideration. The question posed in these matters needs to be answered differently as imparting of education is now a fundamental right. Such a right, therefore, requires a fresh look and not through the glasses of Unni Krishnan. (Paras 47, 58 and 59) Unni Krishnan, J.P. v. Education - Delhi School Education Rules, 1973 - R. 177 - Transfer of fees/funds collected by unaided schools from parents/students from Recognised Unaided School Fund to society/trust running the school a or to any other institution - Bar on, under cl. 8 of Order dated 15-12-1999 issued by Director of Education, Delhi in terms of the Duggal Committee Report, held (per majority), is not in conflict with R. 177 - Reasons for, given - (Per Sinha, J. dissenting) Right to establish and run educational institutions being a fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(g) control or regulation over education or educational institutions within the meaning of Art. 19(6) must be imposed only by a legislative act and not by any executive b instruction - However, the Order dated 15-12-1999 issued by the Director of Education, purportedly under S. 24(3) of the 1973 Act, is beyond the scope thereof, and therefore the said Order does not have the force of law within the meaning of Art. 19(6) - Reasons therefor permitting such schools to utilise their surplus funds to set up more schools, stated - Constitution of India - Art. 19( 6) - "Law" - Meaning of - Executive C instructions whether - Delhi School Education Act, 1973 (18 of 1973) - Ss. 24(3) & (4) - Scope of orders that may be issued under - "Defects and deficiencies" - Meaning of (per Sinha, J.) Question (2 ): Transfer of funds to society/trust or any other institution Held: Per majority d Clause 8 of the Order of the Director of Education [set out in para 11] is not in conflict with Rule 177. Under accounting principles, there is a difference between appropriation of surplus (income) on one hand and transfer of funds on the other hand. Reading Rules 172, 175 and 177, it is clear that appropriation of savings (income) is different from transfer of fund. Under clause 8 of the Order of the Director of Education, the management is restrained from transferring any amount from the Recognised Unaided School Fund to the society or the trust or e any other institution, whereas Rule 177( 1) refers to appropriation of savings (income) from revenue account for meeting capital expenditure of the school. (Para 23) The interpretation that has been placed on the provisions of the said Act is only to bring in transparency, accountability, expenditure management and utilisation of savings for capital expenditure/investment without infringement of f the autonomy of the institute in the matter of fee fixation. It is also to prevent commercialisation of education to the extent possible. (Para 26) Per Sinha, J. ( dissenting) The provisions of the Act and the Rules framed thereunder are absolutely clear and unambiguous. The Supreme Court has to interpret the provisions of the Act and the Rules framed thereunder in the light of the fundamental rights of the g appellants. Any direction, therefore, which would further curtail their fundamental rights would be wholly unwarranted. In view of the fact that plain language has been employed in Rule 177 of the Rules, a strict construction thereof may not be justified. The proviso appended to Rule 177 is not exhaustive. (Paras 57 and 56) The expression "development of education" is a broad term. There does not exist any reason as to why the said right would be limited, regulated or curtailed in absence of any provisions contained in the Act or the Rules framed thereunder. When the law permits utilisation of surplus fund of an institution for setting up another institution, the Court should not come in its way from doing so. (Para 65) The statutory scheme of the Act must be considered also from the point of view that a society running several institutions may have to impart education in different areas; slum, semi-urban or urban. It may not, therefore, be improper for an institution to generate some surplus fund from an institution which is situated within a metropolitan area for the purpose of starting a school in a slum or a semi-urban area as it is permissible in law, the excess income from an institution may be spent by the society/trust to establish another school keeping in view the fact that more and more educational institutions are required to be established particularly in rural or semi-urban area. (Paras 69 and 71) The administration, in the event it comes to the conclusion that the rules are required to be amended, is free to do so; but only because there are a few cases of mismanagement, the same by itself should not be considered to be an indicia that all institutions are being run in an unprofessional or unethical manner. (Para 67) Furthermore, the fundamental right to establish educational institution as contained in Article 19(1)(g) of the Constitution is subject only to the reasonable restrictions which may be imposed by any law in terms of clause (6) thereof. But any control or regulation over education or educational institution must be imposed only by a legislative act and not by any executive instruction. The State, indisputably, can issue directions which should meet the criteria of a "law" within the meaning of Article 13 of the Constitution. (Paras 41 and 4 7) It is not in dispute that pursuant to or in furtherance of the directions issued by the High Court the Duggal Committee was constituted. Pursuant to the recommendations made by the said Committee, a circular dated 15-12-1999 has been issued purported to be in terms of sub-sections (3) and (4) of Section 24 of the Act. The same apparently is beyond the scope and purport of the Act and the Rules as the directions thereunder can be issued only for the purpose of rectifying the defect and deficiencies found at the time of inspection or otherwise in the working of the school and not pursuant to the recommendations made by a committee constituted in terms of a judgment of the High Court. "Defects and deficiencies" within the meaning of the said provisions would mean defects and deficiencies while applying the provisions of the Act and the Rules framed thereunder only and not the recommendations of a committee dehors the Act and the Rules. The said directions, therefore, do not have the force of law within the meaning of Article 19( 6). (Para 4 7) H. For creating such development fund, the management is required to collect development fees. In the present case, pursuant to the recommendation of the Duggal Committee, development fees b could be levied at a rate not exceeding 10% to 15% of total annual tuition fee. Direction 7 of the Order of the Director of Education [set out in para 11] is appropriate. If one goes through the Report of the Duggal Committee, one finds absence of non-creation of specified earmarked fund and further that depreciation has been charged without creating a corresponding fund. Therefore, Direction 7 seeks to introduce a proper accounting practice to be followed by non-business organisations/not-for-profit organisations. With this correct practice c being introduced, development fees for supplementing the resources for purchase, upgradation and replacements of furniture and fixtures and equipments is justified.
